Bassman

Whenever one hears about the Left, they're usually called "progressive", "tolerant", "compassionate", and other glowing remarks. However, conservatives such as myself are always the recipient of some of the most vitriolic hatred from the Left. Rush Limbaugh (yeah, I know, he's a commentator, but so what) says it best when he says that the Left portrays conservatives as a bunch of "racist, sexist, bigot, homophobes". But who are the ones spewing out such hatred?

 Lets look at each of the complaints
 
 Conservatives oppose civil right legislation. Yes or no? If the answer is yes and it is they are racist no matter what the reason behind the oposition.

 Conservatives oppose gay rights on every level from equal marriage to non discrimination. Yes or no? If the answer is yes and it is then they are homophobes.

 Why do people have such a hard time with the term "tolerant"? Tolerance does not mean letting people do whatever they want. That's anarchy.  What I am trying to say, is that some heterosexuals (not me though) think that marriage is strictly between a man and a woman, by definition. Allowing gays to call their partnerships marriage is changing and twisting that meaning of the word. By distorting the meaning of marriage, the word 'marriage' is devalued (not necessarily because they think gays are inferior though), in the same way the word 'love' is devalued when using it at inappropriate times (e.g. I love chocolate). As such, the name given to their relationships is 'devalued'. Because of this, they oppose the name 'marriage' when referring to a gay couple.
 
 I don't hold this opinion though, merely respect the right of others to have it.
 
 -Wez
jim's trucking

Why does this belong in the philosophy section?
Political philosophies shape and separate parties. The thread is not misplaced. It has, as often occurs here, degenerated into a discussion of 'injustices' against gays and lesbians. This generally occurs when narrow-minded, tunnel vision people enter the discussion on their soapboxes.
 
 To begin with, Bassman generalized greatly in the OP. There is no one-sentence descriptor of either the conservative or liberal groups that clearly describes without exception, every member of either group. There is the ever-present bell-shaped curve to consider in every comparison involving large numbers of people. There are conservatives for and against abortion; there are liberals for and against gay marriage. Generalizations serve only to confuse the discussions by miffing those who take exception to being lumped into one group or another simply because of their stance on a single issue. I can understand why very few people welcome being called a 'liberal'. Likewise, 'conservative' may have its offensive facets when the widely accepted definition does not adequately describe the targeted person.
 
 When you say that conservatives believe this and liberals believe that, all you are doing is misinterpreting the true philosophies of many individuals in each group.
 
 I consider myself conservative but I am very much not against abortion under several sets of circumstances. I believe in the death penalty for several crimes. I have compassion for those who can't seem to support themselves, but none for the welfare whores who have children to increase their income. I do not browbeat people to believe as I do, but simply to live, let live and to try not to favor the weakening of our on resolve to live as a free people and to support freedom elsewhere in the world.
 
 I have complete disdain for those who vote against capable and highly qualified nominees simply because the other side made the nomination.
 
 Both sides tend to investigate and criticize the other too much. Well-known leaders from the left seem to ignore failures from within their group as they continually rail on the right for transgressions of similar natures. However, hypocrisy is not peculiar to either side.

As such, the name given to their relationships is 'devalued'. Because of this, they oppose the name 'marriage' when referring to a gay couple.
 
 I don't hold this opinion though, merely respect the right of others to have it.

 And, if your using definitions, note that many reference sources have changed their definitions to include same-sex unions. Some didn't even have to change the definition as the original did not exclude such.
 
 And, once again, I have to say that in comparing the word 'love' and its many uses to the word 'marriage' your analogy is completely off base.
 
 P.S. I also respect the opinions of others. However, I will ask what their opinions are based upon and clarify any fallacies, biases, or stereotypes with truth (even if it is detrimental to my own cause).
hucklebuck

There is no one-sentence descriptor of either the conservative or liberal groups that clearly describes without exception, every member of either group. There is the ever-present bell-shaped curve to consider in every comparison involving large numbers of people. There are conservatives for and against abortion; there are liberals for and against gay marriage. Generalizations serve only to confuse the discussions by miffing those who take exception to being lumped into one group or another simply because of their stance on a single issue. I can understand why very few people welcome being called a 'liberal'. Likewise, 'conservative' may have its offensive facets when the widely accepted definition does not adequately describe the targeted person.
 
 When you say that conservatives believe this and liberals believe that, all you are doing is misinterpreting the true philosophies of many individuals in each group.
 
 I have complete disdain for those who vote against capable and highly qualified nominees simply because the other side made the nomination.
 
 Both sides tend to investigate and criticize the other too much. Well-known leaders from the left seem to ignore failures from within their group as they continually rail on the right for transgressions of similar natures. However, hypocrisy is not peculiar to either side.

 
 I must agree with you on the statements you have made. While I usually vote for the lesser of two evils (it seems) I never wholeheartedly agree with any one candidates position on every issue. I also never speculate to know a persons views based on their political party affiliation. Im glad to see others who are a bit more neutral in their viewpoints.
 
 I also listen to alot of both conservative and liberal talk radio and am never surprised to hear each point out the faults in their "opponents" party without recognizing the faults in their own.
beervolcano

Sure but what if the majority thinks it is wrong, like stealing?

 
 IMO, it doesn't matter what the majority thinks with respect to my rights.
 If the majority said that free speech should abolished, too bad, it can't be.
 If the majority said that guns were outlawed through a congressional act, but not through a constitutional amendment then, too bad, it can't change.
 
 
Not saying the majority is always riight, but we have to have some common ground to work with. The kids should have a choice to go to church. But then again they have to obey their parents or is that an example of stifling a childs rights? 

 The majority cannot revoke the rights of the minority, no matter how much common ground there may be.
 
 
So your saying that the government regulates heterosexual marriages? Tells you who to marry or how to marry? NO. It's only in the legal sense of marriage which I said is ok to give to gay couples. Just dont call it marriage.

 
 No, but to be considered legally married by the state you have to get a license, otherwise your marriage is not legal. Your marriage has to be approved by the state so to speak, and then afterwards different legal status is given to you with respect to taxes, insurance, etc.
 
 Hmm, so it would make you happy just to not call it marriage, but have everything be the same? Strange.
Wez

Wez, seriously, I hear you. I understand that some heterosexuals feel that their marriages may be devalued if gays are allowed to marry. However, what I am arguing is that these fears are irrational and without basis. What do heterosexuals stand to lose if homosexual marriage were made legal? Are their feelings gonna be hurt? Will their pride suffer? 
 
 And, if your using definitions, note that many reference sources have changed their definitions to include same-sex unions. Some didn't even have to change the definition as the original did not exclude such.
 
 And, once again, I have to say that in comparing the word 'love' and its many uses to the word 'marriage' your analogy is completely off base.
 
 P.S. I also respect the opinions of others. However, I will ask what their opinions are based upon and clarify any fallacies, biases, or stereotypes with truth (even if it is detrimental to my own cause).

 I don't hold the opinion I posted, but I still think it's valid. If you take marriage to be a thing between a man and a woman I can see why someone would be offended by same sex partners marrying.
 
 -Wez
daewoo

I don't hold the opinion I posted, but I still think it's valid. If you take marriage to be a thing between a man and a woman I can see why someone would be offended by same sex partners marrying.
 
 -Wez

 
 This has been, IMO the downfall of the same sex marriage movement. At the very outset, thre was wide support for allowing civil unions and giving them the same protections, rights, and privelages under the law as marriage. This wasn't good enough for the gay rights activists who had to have the name, so rather than compromising, they kept pushing. The other side pushed back.
 
 Now, instead of having civil unions, or bethrothals, or whatever other name they might have come up with, same sex marriage has turned into a hot button issue and they have gotten nothing. Was it really worth it over a silly argument about terminology??

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  The Hypocrisy of the Liberal Left
